div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p:
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA,
MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe
for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every
Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for
Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to
LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN,
MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and
SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table
wine free.

Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p:
The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between
Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to
Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation
for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry
proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent
Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to
Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor,
Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to
Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque)
begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the
Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the
scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus
in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.

Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook
& Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY,
General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Sudan Medical Department
div.p: The Sudan Medical Department is in need of the services of a qualified dispenser with pay commencing $16 per mensem. Applications for this post will be addressed to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum. They should be accompanied with all certificates, testimonials, references, etc. and with a duly filled up Application form which is obtainable (together with any info as to pay, increase of pay, conditions of service, etc.) from the Sudan Agency, War Office, Cairo.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: Friday, December 20, 1907.
CRIME IN EGYPT.
A recent issve of the London “Daily News”
tains a letter from “an ian Correspon
t” on the subject of crime in Egypt. That
the gentleman who penned the article in
question is in no way troubled as to whether
his statement contains a moiety of veracity, is
sufficiently evident in the following extracts
which are ludicrous in their absolute disregard
for truth. “Hardly a day passes bat the local
Press chronicle some fearful outrage resulting
in the death of the victims, perpetrated by
armed brigands, banded together for the -
pose of vengeance or plunder. But this is
all. It not unfrequenly happens that o
whole of the inhabitants of neighbouring vil-
lages attack one another, when a species of
pitched battle takes place, many dead and
wonnded being left on the field.” The writer
ot the above remarkable passage goes on to
explain that “the authorities” who are respon
sible tor public security are at their wits end
to discover an effective preventative” and in
conclusion he advocates the formation of a,
commission “to overhaul the administration of
justice from top to bottom.”
‘Our London contemporary is evidently the
possessor of a correspondent who is gifted
with the power of i imagination to a marvellous
degree, or else one who is extraordinarily ea-
sily gulled, for any one who knows anything of
the state of Egypt in the present day, also
knows that though the occurrence of murder
cases are all too frequent, there is no approach
to the state of affairsso luminously described
in the paragraphs which we have quoted above.
Lord Cromer’s much quoted paragraph en the
Particulars of additional intermeaiate
increase of crime is of course paraded as an
undeniable witness of the horror of the situa.
tion, and, we apologise if we are wrong, this
paragraph is introduced with words which
strike us with a distinctly familiar ring. Is it
beyond the bounds of possibility that they
have appeared at no very remote date in the
columns of a local contemporary!
Whatever the motives which prompted the
writer to resort to the extravagancies of which
he is guilty, whether he was really actuated by
& genuine desire to benefit the country by what
he considered to be harmless exaggerations,
penned in the hope that they might attract the
attention of the home Parliament, or whether,
and this weuld seem more probable, he hada
certain space to fill, and conscientiously proceed.
ed to fill it regardless of truth, the very wild-
ness of his assertion will debar it from receiv-
ing serious attention, even by the more ad-
vanced sections of the Radical party at home,
and itis a pity that the which is
responsible for its prodaction Id not have
exercised more care in the editing of their cor-
respondent's work. No good turn was ever serv-
ed by the policy of antruths, and though we do
not doubt bat what our contemporary is guilt-
less of the desire to deceive, it is oéevertheless
unfortanate that it should have become the
medium of pablication for such a letter as that
from which we have quoted.
Asa matter of fact, the sitaation in the
provinces is at last shewing sings of improve
went, which if slight, is
considering the manifold diffieulties which lie
in the way of suppression of crime which has
once got a foothold in such a country as this-
The subject has for a long time been receiving
the active consideration of both the Ministers
of Justice and of the Interior. As we have
previously pointed oat, the change from one
aystem to another is necessarily one which is
franght with unavoidable dangers, and the old
system under which the omdeh reigned ina
state of practical supremacy being no longer
tenable, it was necessary to introducss change,
and it is to this fact that the increase of crime
was primarily due, the newer laws which
demand the swearing of witnesses before con-
viction being unfortunately regarded in the
ixht of leniency, tainted by weakness, by those
who came uuder their jurisdiction.
There is no commission necessary. The Go-
vernment is alive to the fact that exceptional
activity is necessary in the provinces, and all
that it is possible to do is being done, with
the result that as we have already stated, the
more serious offences would already appear to
be checked, and we are of the opinion that
were a commission formed, the members being
of any European country which has had ex-
perience of dealing. with countries such as
Exypt, that their finding would ee justity
the action-of the Government in the matter,
without being able to propound one effective
suggestion which has vot already been applied.
The inauguration of a system empowering the
Government to deport criminals would do much
to strengthen their power in dealing with this
- | question. Many arguments have been brought
to bearagainst this innovation, the chief of
which appears to be that the same code does
not at present hold good in any European
country, the people who bring these argu-
ments forward apparently forgetting that the
prevailing situations are entirely at variance
in the two continents. Deportation was at
one time considered necessary in England,
among other European countries, and the laws
pertaining to it were undoubtedly exercised
with beneticial effect in those early days, but
such is the sickly sentimentality ofa portion
of the present day generation, that the bare
suggestion of the revival of such methods is
regarded with horror, though it is not more
than about sixty years since the same system
was applied at home upon those criminals
who had proved the ineftectuality of more
lenient measures as applied to themselves.
The doctrine of the humane treatment of our
fellows is noble in its every degree, bat the
morbid extension ‘of sympathy to the criminal
classes at the expense of the law-abiding po-
pulation is poisonous in its effect upon a
nation Deported criminals are subjected to
treatment every whit as humane as they
would receive were they located in the local
jail, and why it should be considered necessary
to confine them to local imprisonment at the
expense of the country, when by deporting
them for a period, they would be given every
opportunity of training themselves to become
useful members of society, isa question that
can: never receive a satisfactory reply.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Our Port Said correspondent wires that the
bunkering Arabs cane out on strike last night.
A large aiubis baboon from the Blue Nile
has been presented to the Zoological Gardens,
Cairo, by Wishaw Bey.
The Sabakha Canal Canal will be closed at
its bead near Nezlet Hafiz in Aggiout Province
fora period of thirty days beginning on the
15th of January next.
Mr. F. Reinsperger, the popular manager
of the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria, bas
issued invitations for a Xmas Tree on the 24th
inst. and the fate should prove a great success.
The canals in Fayoum Province will not be
closed to-day as formerly notified. The closure
is postponed till the 26th instant when all
canals will be closed.
The Cairo Branch of “L’Amie de la Jenne
Fille” has delegated an agent of the society to
be stationed at the Cairo station in order to
meet and render assistance to young girls who
are travelling alone.
Our Damanhour correspondent reports that
three natives, including one woman, have been
arrested of the charge of murdering a certain
Abdul Gawad Mouled, whose body was found
on the agricultural road véar Riaz Pashe
station.
Mr Serge Outotchkine will make a balloon
ascent from the Esbekieh gardens at 3 o'clock
on Saturday afternoon. On his second or third
ascent he will be accompanied by Mr. Grosde-
mange, of our contemporary “Progrés.”
The Committee of the London Stock Ex-
change has beén asked to allow the following
security to be quoted in the Official List :—
Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co,
Limited. Further issue of shares of £1 each,
fully paid (bearer warrants’.
The mail for Europe via Port Said and
Brindisi will be made ap at the G.P.O. Alex-
andria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday 22nd for ordin-
ary correspondence, 2.10 p.m. for registered
correspondence, at noon for money orders and
insured articles and at 6 pm on Saturday
21st for parcels
During the month of November nineteen
Sudanese women and nine Sudanese men were
granted manumission papers in Cairo city.
Nine women and three men, also Sudanese,
received them at |Alexandria, and three men
and three womenfall of Sudanese nationality
were also granted them in Suez.
The Telephone Company Egypt,;Ltd., re-
quests us to warn the public against-a gang of
thieves, who, on pretext of carrying « ladder,
pretending to be employed with the company,
have recently entered two buildings, from the
terraces of which they have stolen all they
could find. The police have been advised.
Exhibition of Survey Maps.
His Highness the Kbedive will open the
exhibition of the maps prepared by the Survey
Department, which is to be held in the Geologi
cal Museum in the, gardens of the Public
Works Ministry, on the 9th January next,
after which date the exhibition will be open
to the public from 9 a.m. until 4.30 p.m.
At the annual meeting of the Manchester Cot-
ton Association, Limited, held at Manchester,
Mr. Frederick Reyner, who was in the chair,
referring to Egyptian cotton, said it did not
need much of a prophet to foretell that within
another ten years practically the whole of
the Egyptian cotton used if Lancashire mills
would come vid the Manchester Ship Canal.
Such is the title ot a well got up alvertising
manual and popular guide to Egypt, compiled
by Mr. Weiuthal, assisted by Mr Philip Taylor
and Mr. Holloway. It is in three languages
English, French and German and tie illustra-
tions are excellent. “Egypt”, the special erlition
of “The African World”, for the present season,
is another compilation by Mr Weinthal. Thee
is an interesting article on cotton in Egypt by
Mr. Adolphus Bogdadly
Mr. McKillop has been appointed Chief
Inspector to the Ministry of Finance and the
following appointments to the andermentioned
mudiriehs are also announced: Mr. Dallin, Mr.
Blomfield, and Mohamed Effendi Forad to the
mudirieh of Gharbieh and Galioubieh; Mr.
Barnett Stewart and Mr. Hallis to Behera and
Menoufieh ; Mr. Wild and Mr. Hogg to Dakah-
lieh ; Seleh Effendi Ghirghis to Sharkieb and
Ghizeb ; Salem Effendi Moukbtar to Beni Souef
and Fayoum ; Abdul Aziz Effendi to Minieb ;
Ahmed Effendi Saleh to Assiout and Guirgeh ;
Mobamed Effendi Ramzi to Keneh and As-
souan ; Mobaured Effendi Mousta and Moba-
med Effendi Po for special service.

div.head: Egyptian Politics
div.p: As announced a short time ago in these
columns the moderate nationalists have been
busy organising themselves into a party under
the chairmanship:of Sheikh Ali Bey Yussef.
Convenient premises have been taken on the
first floor of a house nearly opposite the Turf
Club, and in about a week's time all will be
ready for holding the inaugural meeting of the
general committee. Some days ago the Arabic
version of the statutes of the league setting
forth its aim’ and constitution was published,
an Englirh haa of which has just reached
va. The following is an extract :-—
(a) Maintendnce of the Khedivial authority
as guaranted by the Firmans conferring upon
Egypt Administrative Independence.
(b) Reliance upon the pledges given and
declarations made by Great Britain at the
time of the Occupation and claiming their
fulfilment.
(e) A demand for representative institutions
invested with full political and administrative
powers in so far as Egyptians and Egyptian
interests are alone concerned.
(d) Primary Education to be general and
gratuitous.
(e) Arabic to be the medium of instruction
in all Egyptian Government Schools.
(f) Posts in the Egyptian Government to be
given to natives according to their capacity
and merit with the object of diminishing as far
as possible the number of foreigners in the
service of the Government and thus enabling
the Egyptians to learn to govern themselves.
(g) Extension of the Jurisdiction of the
Mixed Courts, which already try civil, com-
mercial and petty offences, to criminal cases in
which foreigners -are concerned until such
period as it may be possible to inaugurate
unity of Jurisdiction and thus affirm the great
principle of justice for all who inbabit the same
country, namely, “Equality before the Law.”
The leagve’s chief office is in Cairo bat it
is contemplated establishing branches in all the
principal towns of Egypt. An administrative
council consisting of fifteen members selected
from a general committee unlimited in num-
bers, and which has already been extensively
joined, will carry out the arrangements of the
league. Members of the committee will pay
an entrance fee of L.E. 2 and an annual sub-
| scription of LE. 5, whilst ordinary members
will be admitted on payment of P.T. 20 and an
an annual subscription of P.T. 560. One of the
rules contains a very salutary provision, name-
ly, that religious topics shall be excluded
from discussion save 80 far as the management
of religions institations is concerned. The
meaning of this is that whilst the league shal!
he free to criticise the administration of
ecclesiastical endowments such as the Wakfs
and Al-Azhar “with a view to introducing
feforms of, general utility” it shall not lay
itself open to the charge of promoting Pau
Islamic propaganda. For the rest, the aims
of the league do not present any feature
sicenien develty or disconcerting tendencies.
All the claims put forward have been already
foreshadowed in the speeches and manifestoes
of Sheikh Ali Yaissef and Hafiz Effendi Awad.
Political groupingsin Egypt resolve themselves
into three sections, the first of which demands
the evacuation of the English from the Nile
Valley unconditionally, the second, so soon as
the Egyptians shal] become capable of govern-
ing themselves and have given proof that by
the departure of the English political and com-
mercial interests shall not be injured ; and the
third desire to remain for ever under British
tutelage. Needless to add that the second
section is represented by the league Its
demands, however remote some of them may
he from realisation, are certainly concluded in
language of scrupulous moderation, and are
not calculated to wound the susceptibilities of
the most staunch Imperialist. It is to the credit
of the founder of this movement and his coad-
jutors that they should have framed a body
of rules which are on the whole clear and com
prehensive. Their programme, too, has been
well reeeived by the Arabic Press and the
public whith had beeome confused by a ple
thora of political programmes and nau-
sented by the fanfaronade and _ rhetorical
falsetto of Mustapha Pasha Kamel. Little to
the liking of this frothy phrase-monger must be
the evergy displayed by his nationalist compe-
titors in completing sach an organisation which
has already been formed by some of the most
aceompilshed writers in the Arabic Republic
ot Letters. He feels evidently that some
counter effort must be made and he theretore
proposes to pronounce one of his illuminating
dixcourses on the 27th inst. before a meeting
of the so called nationalist party, when he will
discuss the object of his party about which he
has for long years taken good care that the
public shall be in no doubt. We may therefore
expect nothing but a rechauf/# of his “Anglais
et Egyptiens” seasoned with choice morsels
from the Zizinia oration, But there is to be
something more. No utterance of his would be
complete without an out-pouring of the vials
of his wrath upon those who dare to differ
from bim. So we are to be regaled with an
account of the machinations employed by his
enemies in attacking him. Who ever said that
he recognises only two classes of men—tools
and enemies—was probably not far from the
mark. And as a final bonne bouche he will
demonstrate in an eloquent peroration— Kamel
is nothing if not eloquent—of the tub-thum-
ping order, that his party consisting of his
brother# bis sisters bis cousins and his aunts
is the only—the very only—one which cen
Egypt, where too there is a political awakening,
ag well as in India. In Europe, the formation
of a political organisation is such sn every-
day affair that it attracts but little or no atten-
tion. Here, however, being an entirely new
experiment, it is regarded in native circles as
an event of considerable importance. For our-
selves we can Only say that we shall watch its
development with interest unmixed with
anxiety.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: Prince and Princess Windischgraets are stay-
ing at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan.
Mr. Winston Churchill has now passed the
frontier of the Egyptian Sudan. On the 4th
inst. he passed through Wadelai, which is 206
miles from Gondokoro and 112 miles from
Nanuli, the headquarters of the Nile Province
and the residence of an assistant commissioner.
Sir Eldon-and Lady Gorst with Sir William
Garstin will leave for Upper Egypt and the
Sudan on Thursday next and will meet Mr.
Churchill at Assouan.
Sir Eldon will return to Cairo on the 26th
proxo.
Lady Alexander Paget is setting out from
London for Cairo to join her son, Lord Angle-
sey, who has jast returned from big game
shooting in South Africa. Lady Paget proposes
visiting Paris and Naples en route, after which
she and her son will go up the Nile together.
Lord Vivian, who,as a special cable we publish-
ed on Wednesday from London announced, has
succeeded in divorcing his wife in the suit in
which the co ndent was the well-known
Anglo Egyptian financier, Mr. Alfred Curphey,
is quite a young man, having not yet attained
thirty. He isthe fourth holder of a Barony
created in 1841 and is also a Baronet, a title
created in 1828. The first Baroh was Equerry
to the “First Gentleman in Europe” and subse-
quently became Commander of the Forces in
Ireland’and Master General of the Ordnance.
The present Peer is the son of the third Baron,
and his mother was the daughter of R. G. Duff,
of Ryde, Isle of Wight. He succeeded to the
title on the death of his father in 1893. He was
educated at Bton and joined the 17th Lancers.
In the Sonth African War he was severely
wounded His seat is at Glynn, near Bodmin,
and heis the owner of about 8,300 acres. Previ-
ous to the birth of his only son, the heir to the
title was his cousin, Anthony Vivian, of the
Rifle Brigade.
Mrs. Bullock will not be ‘‘At Home” on
Sunday afternoon next.
Dr. Bedloe, of Washington D.C., returned
from America to Egypt on Monday last by the
North German Lloyd Steamer “Hohensollern”
and will spend the holidays in Alexandria with
his old collegeclass-mate Dr. Love, after which
they will make the tour of the Nile and
Sudan.
A sad accident occurred yesterday afternoon
aboard the Norwegian 8.8. “Hiemw.” Mr. A.
Principe, who had been sent by the Mixed
Tribunals as an expert to examine some daw-
aged cargo, was standing by an open hold,
when he slipped and fell down head first to
the bottom ; his head struck against an iron
bar and fractured the skull, causing instan-
taneous death.
The German training ship “Stein” arrived
in Alexandria harbour this morning.
The Ellerman liner “Assiout” arrived at
Liverpool last Wednesday. |

div.head: Telegrams.
div.p: Conducted by the Pope.
Rome, December 19.
The Pope personally conducted this morning
the of the Pablic Consistory,.attended by thousands of invited persons, especially
including many English speaking”
extraneous to the ceremony gathered
in special placea, while the Cardinals, Prelates,
and “Court” personages assembled to await the
Pontiff in another hall. Meanwhile the Cardi-
nals created on Monday, and Cardinals Rinal-
dini and Ageirre y Garcia, created in the last
Consistory, ired to the Sistine Chapel,
where they took their oath of office before the
chiefs of the three orders of Cardinals.
In the procession first came the Swiss Guards
followed by the personages of the ecclesiastical
His Holiness, in complete pontifical robes,
was walking on foot blessing as he went. Fol-
lowing him came ahother long train of person-
ages, together with the Sis tine Choir.
The Pope mounted the throne amid 4 res-
pectful silence The sew Cardinals were then
introduced and while kneeling one by one st
the Pontiff’s feet he repeated the formula
“accipe galeram rubrum.” Then, separately,
after the papal embrace, went to each of the
Cardinals and received a fraternal salute, the
choir meanwhile singing. After the ceremony
was over Pius K. rose, and gave the apostolic
blessing and slowly withdrew, the procession
reforming as ap escort.
Later, Pius X. held a short supplementary
Secret Consistory. ( Reuter)
NO POLITICAL IMPORTANCE.
Berlin, December 18.
In official circles here the Abou Moussa
(Persian Gulf) incident is considered as @ pure- |.
ly judicial affair and without any political
importance.
An Arab had given a concession for the
working of a mine on the Island and the con-
cessionaires bad concluded a contract for hand-
ing it over to a German house.
The Sheikh who possesses the sovereignty
of the Island is under British protectorate. He
considered this contract as constituting a mo-
nopoly for the German house and was under
the impression that he had the right of can-
celling it.
The sta
a store of
tion. The
friedly negotia
ment regarding
ts regarding the existence of
san arms are avoid of founda. |
Government has begun
ions with the British Govern-
matter. ( Reuter)
ee
Teheran, December 19.
The people assembled in the Midan and be-
fore the Parliament House dispersed on the an-
nouncement' that negociations were being car-
ried on between the Shah and Parliament and
would otherwise would be suspended. Things
looked bopeful until in the afternoon shots
were fired in the Midan, when tents were re
pitched and the people reassembled. (Reuter)
Patermo, December 20.
An explosion has occurred in a store of ex-
plosives. The store and a hotel above collapsed.
The hotel was full of emigrants, 17 of whom
are dead. 71 wounded persons have been ex-
tracted from the ruins: many are missing.
( Reuter)

div.head: SUDAN GOLD FIELD.

p.hi: NO REASON TO BE OTHER THAN

div.p: The fourth ordinary general meeting of the
shareholders of the Sudan Gold Field, Limited,
was held on the 11th December, 1907, at No.6,
Queen Street Place, E.C., the Right Hon.
Lord Vanx of HarrowJen presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. W.F. Garland) having
read the notice convening the meeting and the
auditors’ report.
The Chairman said : Gentlemen, you have
no doubt all carefuily stadied the directors’
report, as well as the balance-sheet to June
80th last, recently issued. Mr. Robert Taylor
will, as usual, describe to you the mining
details in regard to our last year’s work. Turn-
ing to the balance-sheet, at June 30th, being
the date to which the accounts are made up,
there had been called up upon the 155,000
cash shares 15s per share, leaving a liability of
bs per shate The comparatively large amount
outstanding on calls, viz, £%,626 188, was due
to the fagt that a call became payable on June
Ist, and that some of the amounts has not
been received at the time the accounts were
made up. They” were, however, paid shortly
after. The expenditure for the twelve months
under the heading of “Mining and general
expenditure,” amounted to £21675 Is 7d. We
deduct £42 lls 3d received as transfer fees,
interest, etc., leaving £21,832 10s 4d. This
includes £1,617 1s 5d written off for deprecia-
tion of buildings, machinery, plant, and rolling
stock, which is less than the amount written
off for the previous year, when the account
was dealt with in a somewhat more drastic
manner than will again become necessary. The
expenditure on capital account for the twelve
months was £6,322 12s 4d. The items are fully
set out in detail in the repert. Since June
80th, at which date we had a balance of work-
ing capital of £42,531 1s 6d,a further 2s 2d
per share has been called up, the last call being
payable on November 4th At the present
moment our balance of working capital is about
We think you will have come to the con-
clusion, after reading the directors’ report, that
we have no reason to be other than satisfied
with the considerable progress which has been
made at the mine during the past year, and
with the favourable features which the under-
fature. Indeed, I look upon the history
Water supply at Nabardi as one of the most i
teresting episodesin the history of the mine.
When Mr. Liewelyn first visited Nabardi in 1901
there was practically no water there at all. After
some months’ work witha view to proving the
presence of gold, and having acquired the
practical certainty of the mine being likely to
turn out productive, the water question be-
came one of vital importance, and a
boring plant was despatched, and some consi-
derable time was spent in searching before a
supply was found sufficient to provide for the
needs of a camp such as would be necessary to
develop the mine. Since that time the sapply
of water at Nabardi and in its immediate
neighbourhood has steadily increased, and our
chief service of supply is now likely to be the
Maftah well, which is about 16 miles from the
mine. That well was originally commenced
with the idea that, being in sandstone forma-
tion, the chances of finding water were excep-
tionally good, for the sandstone is traceable
for some ten miles in length until it reaches a
range of bills, and it is some two miles in
width, and such a formation might naturally
be expected to form a sort of catchment area
for the drainage of the hills. The depth of the
sandstone has not yet been ascertained. The
well is at present 190 ft. deep, and is indicat-
ing @ probable increased supply as we ‘go
| deeper, it may be mentioned that, whilst at
182 ft it gave 600 gallons per 24 hours, on
being continued another 8 ft the quantity
increased to 7,000 gallons. It is, therefore, not
unreasonable to assume that from this source
we shall get a satisfactory and continuous
supply.
Reviewing the whole position, the directors
recently came to the conelusion that, as the
mine has now reached a stage of development
warranting the erection of a mill, there is no
longer any reason why the mill should not be
installed at the mine itself Until the ore
reserves can be more increased the
direetors have thought it advisable to erect a
10-stamp mill only, to be added to as cireum-
stances render it necessary and expedient.
About the time this decision was come to your
directors were informed that an opportunity
was presenting itself to acquire a mill ata
mine in Egypt which las now discontinued
operations. Your directors caused this mill to
be inspected, and, it having been found to be in
good condition, it has since been purchased,
and is now on its way to the property. I may
say that owing to the distance of the Muftah
well from the mine, and the consequent neces-
sity for a long pipe-line to carry the water, the
cost of erecting the mill at Nabardi and getting
all ready for a start will be much the same as it
we had erected it on the Nile, but there will
be a considerable saving in running it, as the
ore will not now have to be carried 180 miles
for treatment. Moreover, there will be not only
economy, but also many other advantages in
treating the ore on the spot, instead of having
to keep op a separate establishment on the
Nile for that parpose. Before finally determin.
ing what treatment beyond amalgamation will
be required to extract the highest possible per-
centage of the gold contents of the ore, the
directors are awaiting the complete result of
some tests being carried out by a London firm
ona bulk sample from the deeper develop-
ments at the mine. So far as the tests have
gone, thére would appear to be every probabi-
lity that the extraction will be satisfactory.
For milling, it is proposed to utilise the water
from the Muftah well, and the necessary pipe-
line to convey it to the mill site is in course of
shipment. It is not certajp as to how soon the
mill may be in operation, but we are quite hop-
ing that we shall be able to make a start in
May at the latest. Throughout the past year
the native labour supply has been ample, and
we are glad to say that the health of the camp
has continued good.
You will notice that our superintendent,
Mr. Holman, retains a very favourable opinion
of our prospects, and considers that we ate
working upon a true fissure vein, upon which
we should vpen up a valuable mine. Although
outside of the Om Nabardi mining lease we
are at present doing no work, yet, in view of
the possibilities in connection with the conces-
sion, we have felt desirous of keeping our hold
upon the 22,000 square miles originally granted

div.head: Sport and Play
div.p: INTERSECTION COMPETITION
FIRST ROUND.
(From a CoRRESPONDENT. )
No. 1 Section # No. 8 Section.
The above two well-known old rivals met at
Ras-el-Tin in the above competition. Both
teams were at full strength and considering the
ground was in the pink of condition, a good
game was in store for those who lined the ropes.
At exactly 8.30 p.m. the referee lined his men
out. The stripes won the toss and MoArthor
800 spectators. Play was very fast at the start
and the stripes defence was severely pressed.
Walsh and Tripp narrowly missed scoring.
Midfield play now followed until McArthur
burst away and following a rush on the stripes
citadel the sphere was landed in the net,
McArthur doing the needful. On tesuming,
play took a turn towards Boyd and Company.
The latter were however in splendid form,
especially Skelly, time and again the latter
saved the position when all seemed lost, the
greens now tvok play in hand and succeeded
in getting a corner which proved fruitless.
McArthor spoiled a good chance by lying off
side. Play was very even, both teams doing their
utmost.
Skelly was very conspicuous in the greens
defence while Reynolds for the stripes display-
ed wonderful form. The stripes now took play towards Boyd and Company, the former being cheered for a praiseworthy save; play raged fast and furious from this to the interval, the score then reading.
No. 8 Section R. A. M. C. — 1 Goal.
No. 1 Section R. A. M. C.— = Nid.

div.head: AVIS
div.p:
La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des
Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.

Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être
consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés
exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 24 December 1907.

Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même
jour à 5h.p.m.

L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de
prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 24 December à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 13 December 1907.
